unnormalised: A Delhi court has extended the judicial custody of Vijay Mallya till 22/07/2024 in connection with the alleged Rs. 9,000 crore bank loan default case. Mallya, facing charges under IPC Sections 420 (cheating) and 120B (criminal conspiracy), was presented before the court via video conferencing from London. The Enforcement Directorate (ED) has filed multiple charge sheets against him.
normalised: A Delhi court has extended the judicial custody of Vijay Mallya till twenty second july two thousand and twenty four in connection with the alleged rupee nine billion bank loan default case. Mallya, facing charges under I-P-C Sections four hundred and twenty (cheating) and one hundred and twenty B (criminal conspiracy), was presented before the court via video conferencing from London. The Enforcement Directorate (E-D) has filed multiple charge sheets against him.

unnormalised: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) is also pursuing extradition proceedings. The court, presided over by Judge Sharma, noted the slow pace of extradition hearings in the UK. Adv. Khanna, representing the CBI, argued for continued custody, citing the risk of Mallya fleeing to another jurisdiction.
normalised: The Central Bureau of Investigation (C-B-I) is also pursuing extradition proceedings. The court, presided over by Judge Sharma, noted the slow pace of extradition hearings in the U-K. Advocate Khanna, representing the C-B-I, argued for continued custody, citing the risk of Mallya fleeing to another jurisdiction.

unnormalised: Mallya's lawyers, led by Sr. Adv. Agarwal, contended that the charges are politically motivated and that the loans were legitimate business transactions. They presented documents arguing that Kingfisher Airlines had suffered losses due to unforeseen circumstances. The next hearing is scheduled for 22/07/2024 at 10:30 AM.
normalised: Mallya's lawyers, led by Senior Advocate Agarwal, contended that the charges are politically motivated and that the loans were legitimate business transactions. They presented documents arguing that Kingfisher Airlines had suffered losses due to unforeseen circumstances. The next hearing is scheduled for twenty second july two thousand and twenty four at ten thirty A-M.

unnormalised: The case, registered under FIR no. RC2212015A0001, has been a subject of intense media scrutiny. The Supreme Court has also intervened, directing Mallya to disclose his assets. The ED has attached properties worth Rs. 14,000 crore in connection with the case.
normalised: The case, registered under F-I-R no. R-C-two two one two zero one five A zero zero zero one, has been a subject of intense media scrutiny. The Supreme Court has also intervened, directing Mallya to disclose his assets. The E-D has attached properties worth rupee fourteen billion in connection with the case.
